Sir Isaac Newton, widely recognized for his work on the laws of motion and universal gravitation, also made significant contributions to the field of optics. One of his notable achievements in this area was discovering that white light is composed of different colors. This discovery was detailed in his book "Opticks," which was published in 1704.

This information can be found in various sources, including academic articles and educational websites that discuss the history of science and Newton's contributions. For instance, the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy has an entry on the history of quantum mechanics that mentions Newton's work in optics.
